titleStmt.title: The progress of dulness, part second: or An essay on the life and character of Dick Hairbrain, of finical memory; being an astronomical calendar, calculated for the meridian of New-York, north latitude, 41^o. West longitude 72^o:30'; but which may serve without material error, for any of the neighboring climates: containing, among other curious and surprizing particulars, Dick's soliloquy on a college-life--a description of a country-fop---receipt to make a gentleman, with the fop's creed and exposition of the Scriptures---Dick's gradual progress from a clown to a coxcomb---his travels, gallantry, and opinion of the ladies---his peripaetia and catastrophe, with the moral and application of the whole. : Published for the universal benefit of mankind.
titleStmt.author: Trumbull, John, 1750-1831.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 40 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 27 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The progress of dulness, part second: or An essay on the life and character of Dick Hairbrain, of finical memory; being an astronomical calendar, calculated for the meridian of New-York, north latitude, 41^o. West longitude 72^o:30'; but which may serve without material error, for any of the neighboring climates: containing, among other curious and surprizing particulars, Dick's soliloquy on a college-life--a description of a country-fop---receipt to make a gentleman, with the fop's creed and exposition of the Scriptures---Dick's gradual progress from a clown to a coxcomb---his travels, gallantry, and opinion of the ladies---his peripaetia and catastrophe, with the moral and application of the whole. : Published for the universal benefit of mankind.

notesStmt.note: Attributed to John Trumbull in BAL.

"Advertisement. To be published by the next commencement ... The progress of dulness, part third and last."--p. [28]. Ascribed to the press of Thomas and Samuel Green, who are named in the imprint of the third part.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The Progre≈øs of DULNESS. PART SECOND.

The Progre≈øs of DULNESS, PART SECOND: OR AN ESSAY On the LIFE and CHARACTER of DICK HAIRBRAIN, OF FINICAL MEMORY; Being an A≈øtronomical Calendar, Calculated for the Meridian of New-York, North Latitude, 41¬∞. We≈øt Longitude 72¬∞; 30'; but which may ≈øerve without material Error, for any of the neighbouring Climates:

CONTAINING, Among other curious and ≈øurprizing Particulars, DICK'S Soliloquy on a College-Life‚Äîa De≈øcription of a Country-Fop‚ÄîReceipt to make a Gentleman, with the Fop's Creed and Expo≈øition of the Scriptures‚ÄîDick's gradual Progre≈øs from a Clown to a Coxcomb‚ÄîHis Travels, Gallantry, and Opinion of the Ladies‚ÄîHis Peripaetia and Cata≈øtrophe, with the Moral and Application of the whole.
Publi≈øhed for the univer≈øal Benefit of Mankind.

IT is become an univer≈øal cu≈øtom for every Author, before he gives him≈øelf up to the fury of the Critics, to make his dying ≈øpeech in a Preface; in which, according to the u≈øual ≈øtyle of criminals, he confe≈ø≈øes his faults, tells the temptations that led him to the crime of ≈øcribbling, gives good advice to the re≈øt of his fraternity, and throws him≈øelf upon the mercy of the Court. The≈øe ≈øpeeches are commonly addre≈ø≈øed to a ≈øort of imaginary being, called the kind, courteous, candid and ≈øometimes, benevolent Reader. Not that I would deny the exi≈øtence of ≈øuch a being, as an Epicurean once did of the ≈øoul, becau≈øe he could not find an account of it, in the complete zoology of animals. The fir≈øt part of this Poem met with very kind reception from many of this cla≈øs: nor am I concerned lea≈øt the ≈øecond ≈øhould receive any ill u≈øage from them. Authors have much more to fear from readers of a different ≈øtamp; and though we are u≈øually loth to ≈øpeak out ≈øo plainly, the truth is, we ≈øhould not make ≈øuch long prologues to the Candid, were we a≈ø≈øured of our ≈øafety from the attacks of the Malicious. For my own part, being an enemy to ceremony and circumlocution, and having moreover ≈øome out≈øtanding accounts to ≈øettle, I ≈øhall directly addre≈øs my≈øelf to this la≈øt kind of Critic;
a≈ø≈øuring him however, upon my word of honour, that I was not moved to do him this homage, as the Indians are to wor≈øhip the devil, out of any fear of his power to do mi≈øchief; ≈øince I have already experienced that his malice has its proper antidote in his impotence.

opener.salute: To the Envious and Malicious Reader.

body.head: May it plea≈øe your Wor≈øhip, or your Reverence; or your Illnature, by what title ≈øoever dignified and di≈øtingui≈øhed:

p.hi: AS you have expre≈ø≈øed great re≈øentment again≈øt the fir≈øt part of this Poem and its Author, you might perchance think your≈øelf ≈ølighted, if I ≈øhould let the ≈øecond come abroad without paying you my proper acknowledgements. I own my≈øelf much your debtor; and am only ≈øorry that the number of your brotherhood is ≈øo incon≈øiderable, that the world may perhaps think this dedication almo≈øt entirely needle≈øs. Had a greater number ≈øhown them≈øelves affected, I ≈øhould have had more grounds to hope that the Poem might be u≈øeful. Satire is a medicine very ≈øalutary in its effects, but quite unplea≈øant in its operation; nor do I know a more evident ≈øymptom that the potion has taken its proper effect, than the groans and di≈øtortions of the Patient.

body.p:
I had the plea≈øure, my Illnatured Reader, on the fir≈øt publication of my poem, to hear the remarks made upon it by a clu≈øter of your fraternity, who might each of them have ≈øate for the picture of Tom Brainle≈øs. And as you may have frequent
occa≈øion to talk again≈øt it your≈øelf, and yet be at ≈øome lo≈øs what to alledge in its reproach, I will do you the favor to acquaint you with the re≈øult of their critici≈øms; in order to ≈øave you the trouble of ≈øo much thinking, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt you a little in the ≈øtyle and expre≈ø≈øion of your re≈øentments.

It was determined by the meeting, nem. con. that the whole piece was low, paltry ≈øtuff, and both ≈øcurrilous in the ≈øentiments and dirty in the ≈øtyle; that it was evident, the Author knew nothing of language, or ver≈øification, and was incapable of writing with any degree of elegance; that he was an open reviler of the Clergy, and an enemy to truth and learning; that his apparent de≈øign was to ridicule religion, di≈øgrace morality, ≈øneer at the pre≈øent methods of education, and in ≈øhort, write a ≈øatire upon Yale-College and the ten commandments; that he treated the ≈øubject in the mo≈øt partial and prejudiced manner, and mu≈øt certainly be either a Separati≈øt, or a Sandemanian. Though the truth of the a≈ø≈øertions in the poem could not ≈øo conveniently be denied, yet much was ≈øaid again≈øt the intention of the Author; and it was affirmed that if indeed the world in one or two points was not quite ≈øo good, as they could wi≈øh it, yet things in the pre≈øent ≈øtate could never be altered for the better, and it was folly, or madne≈øs alone could propo≈øe it.

Now to give you as much light as po≈ø≈øible into this matter, I would a≈ø≈øure you, the Author had very little hopes that the world would, in his day, arrive at the point of perfection, from which it is at pre≈øent he knows not how many leagues di≈øtant; and his expectations are not very ≈øanguine, that
the≈øe pictures of the modern defective manners will do much ≈øervice. He is fully ≈øen≈øible, that the moral World is as difficult to be moved out of its cour≈øe, as the natural; that there is in it as much power of re≈øi≈øtance or vis inertiae, as the Philo≈øophers term it; and that the projectors are equally at a lo≈øs for engines and foothold. He is as much ≈øati≈øfied that the pre≈øent year hath borne a ≈øufficient number of fools to keep up the breed, as that there has been a tolerable crop produced every ≈øea≈øon, for the≈øe forty years pa≈øt. But he thought, though perhaps the picture might not reclaim many, there could be no harm in trying his hand at the draught: In which, if the good people, who ≈øate for the painting, have the ill hap to find them≈øelves drawn with a wide mouth, a long no≈øe, or a blear eye, he begs of them to get a little acquainted with their own faces, and ≈øee whether the≈øe be not their real defects of nature, before they begin to rail at the Painter, for the badne≈øs of their re≈øemblance.

I am fully ≈øen≈øible, my Illnatured Reader, that you have good rea≈øons in your own brea≈øt, to account for your re≈øentment again≈øt my fir≈øt e≈ø≈øay, and direct you in the manner of your remarks. You ought in gratitude to defend that carele≈ø≈øne≈øs in the examination of Candidates for preaching, to which it is not at all impo≈ø≈øible, but you may your≈øelf be indebted for your reverence and your band. Ju≈øtly may you de≈øpi≈øe the ≈øtudy of tho≈øe finer Arts and Sciences, of which, in a ≈ømooth journey through life, you never once knew the want, or perceived the advantages: ju≈øtly ≈øhould you undervalue them in compari≈øon with that antient Learning, which
from experience you rightly term Solid, as your own wits were never able to penetrate it. With good rea≈øon al≈øo do you affirm the ≈øatire to be levelled at the Clergy in general, ≈øince that a≈ø≈øertion is the be≈øt method of preventing the public from dragging to view tho≈øe particular men, at whom it is, and ought to be, pointed; though you might di≈øcern, with any other eye than that of wilful prejudice, that the Author hath the highe≈øt veneration for the mini≈øterial robe, or he would never thus trouble him≈øelf about the ≈øpots that defile it. As for tho≈øe, however dignified in ≈øtation, who rail at the Progre≈øs of Dulne≈øs, to gain favour with a particular party, or order of men, he thinks them unworthy the notice of an an≈øwer. He would hint only to ≈øuch as hope to ≈øcreen them≈øelves in the croud, and draw on him the re≈øentment of tho≈øe he e≈øteems, by affirming the ≈øatire to be general, that he would thank them, if they would ≈øo far throw off the ma≈øk, that by acquiring a right to their names, he may have an opportunity hereafter to render it more particular. He e≈øpecially recommends this hint to two Per≈øons, the haughtie≈øt Dullard, and the mo≈øt impertinent Coxcomb of this age; from whom he has already received numberle≈øs favours, and who by their future good conduct may ≈øtand a chance, at ≈øome fortunate period, to figure at the head of a Dedication to the fir≈øt and ≈øecond parts of the Progre≈øs of Dulne≈øs.

p.hi:
And new, my Evil Reader, with regard to the Poem before you, which is properly a counterpart to the other, I de≈øign pretty much to let it ≈øpeak for it≈øelf. Perhaps, ≈øince I have now endeavoured to ridicule and explode both extremes, this ≈øecond part may a≈ø≈øi≈øt you a little to judge what are
the ≈øentiments I would wi≈øh to enforce: but in plain truth, I have very little hopes of you. Neverthele≈øs before I leave you, I will tell you one ≈øecret, and give you a few words of advice. The ≈øecret, which I am ≈øure you would never have been able to di≈øcover, is this; In conformity to the delicacy of your ta≈øte, I have rai≈øed the ≈øtyle of this part, about two degrees by the ≈øcale, higher than the other. The advice is, that it will be no unwi≈øe proceedure in you to hint that the ≈øpirit of the piece is not well ≈øupported, nor this part half ≈øo good as the fir≈øt: and an ob≈øervation, or two, upon the Author's impudence, ≈øea≈øonably introduced, might not be wholly without effect. But as to the old trite way of calling men, Heretics, Dei≈øts and Arminians, it hath been lately ≈øo much hackneyed and worn out by ≈øome Reverend Gentlemen, that I cannot promi≈øe it would do you any manner of ≈øervice.

body.p: I cannot conclude without declaring to the world in this public manner, that whoever ≈øhall take on him≈øelf this character, by criticizing on the≈øe Poems in the method above ≈øpecified, ≈øhall have my free licence and permi≈ø≈øion to appropriate to him≈øelf the whole of this dedication, and be di≈øtingui≈øhed for the future by the title of my Envious and Malicious Reader: and I do a≈ø≈øure him that this preface was written purpo≈øely for him; not de≈øigning however to exclude from a proper ≈øhare every one, who ≈øhall join with him in tho≈øe ≈øentiments, from this fir≈øt day of January, new ≈øtyle, A. D. 1773, henceforth, and as long as the world ≈øhall endure, be the ≈øame term longer or ≈øhorter.

postscript.p: P. S. I Wi≈øh you a happy New-year.

lg.l: 'TWAS in a town remote (the place
We leave the reader wi≈øe to gue≈øs;
For readers wi≈øe can gue≈øs full well,
What authors never meant to tell)
There dwelt ≈øecure a Country-clown,
The wealthie≈øt Farmer of the town;
Tho' rich by villainy and cheats,
He bought re≈øpect by frequent treats;
Gain'd offices by con≈øtant ≈øeeking,
Squire, Captain, Deputy and Deacon;
Great was his pow'r; his pride as arrant:
One only Son his heir apparent.
He thought the Stripling's parts were quick,
And vow'd to make a man of Dick;
Ble≈øs'd the pert dunce, and prais'd his looks,
And put him early to his books.
More oaths than words Dick learn'd to ≈øpeak,
And ≈øtudied knav'ry more than greek;
Three years at ≈øchool, as u≈øual, ≈øpent,
Then all equipt to College went,
And pleas'd in pro≈øpect, thus be≈øtow'd
His meditations, as he rode.
"All hail, unvex'd with care and ≈øtrife,
The bli≈øs of Academic Lfe;
Where kind repo≈øe protracts the ≈øpan,
While Childhood ripens into man;
Where no hard parent's dreaded rage
Curbs the gay ≈øports of youthful age;
Where no vile fear the Genius awes
With grim ≈øeverity of laws;
Where annual troops of Bucks come down,
The flow'r of ev'ry neighb'ring town;
Where wealth and pride and riot wait,
And ev'ry rogue may find his mate.
Far from tho≈øe walls, from plea≈øure's eye,
Let care and grief and labour fly,
The toil to gain the laurel-prize.
That dims the anxious ≈øtudent's eyes,
The pedant-air of learned looks,
And long fatigue of turning books.
Let poor, dull rogues, with weary pains,
To college come to mend their brains,
And drudge four years, with grave concern,
How they may wi≈øer grow and learn.
Is wealth of indolence afraid,
Or does wit need pedantic aid?
The man of wealth the world de≈øcries,
Without the help of learning, wi≈øe;
The magic pow'rs of gold, with ea≈øe,
Transform us to what ≈øhape we plea≈øe,
Give knowledge bright and courage brave,
And wits, that nature never gave.
But nought avails the hoarded trea≈øure;
In ≈øpending only lies the plea≈øure.
There Vice ≈øhall lavi≈øh all her charms,
And Rapture fold us in her arms,
Riot ≈øhall court the frolic ≈øoul,
And Swearing crown the ≈øparkling bowl;
While Wit ≈øhall ≈øport with va≈øt applau≈øe,
And ≈øcorn the feeble tie of laws;
Our midnight joys no rule ≈øhall bound,
While games and dalliance revel round.
Such plea≈øures youthful years can know,
And Schools there are, that ≈øuch be≈øtow.
And oh, that School how greatly ble≈øt,
By fate di≈øtingui≈øh'd from the re≈øt,
Who≈øe ≈øeat is fix'd on ≈øacred ground,
By Venus' nunn'ries circled round;
Where not, like monks, in durance hard,
From all the joys of love debarr'd,
The ≈øolitary Youth in pain
For rapture ≈øighs, yet ≈øighs in vain:
But kind occa≈øion prompts de≈øire
And crowns the gay, licentious fire,
And Plea≈øure courts the ≈øons of Science,
And Whores and Mu≈øes hold alliance.

Not Tho≈øe "There is a certain Region on the We≈øtern Continent, ≈øituated within the northern temperate Zone, where in ≈øome of the mo≈øt notable and re≈øpectable Schools, not only Indolence & Dulne≈øs, but almo≈øt every Crime, may by the rich be aton'd for with pecuniary ≈øatisfaction." Dudon's Geographical Paradoxes. No. 45. so ble≈øt, for ea≈øe and ≈øport,
Where Wealth and Idlene≈øs re≈øort,
Where free from cen≈øure and from ≈øhame,
They ≈øeek of learning, but the name,
Their crimes of all degrees and ≈øizes
Aton'd by golden ≈øacrifices:
Where kind in≈øtructors fix their price,
In ju≈øt degrees on ev'ry vice,
And fierce in zeal 'gain≈øt wicked cour≈øes,
Demand repentance‚Äîof their pur≈øes;
Till ≈øin, thus tax'd, produces clear
A copious income ev'ry year,
And the fair Schools thus free from ≈øcruples,
Thrive by the knav'ry of their Pupils.
Ev'n thus the Pope, long ≈øince has made
Of human crimes a gainful trade;
Keeps ev'ry plea≈øing vice for ≈øale,
For ca≈øh, by whole≈øale, or retail.
There, pay the prices and the fees,
Buy rapes, or lies, or what you plea≈øe,
Then ≈øin ≈øecure, with firm reliance,
And bid the ten commands defiance.
And yet, alas, the≈øe happie≈øt Schools
Pre≈øerve a ≈øet of mu≈øty rules,
And in their wi≈øe≈øt progre≈øs ≈øhow,
Perfection is not found below.
Ev'n there, indulg'd, in humble ≈øtation,
Learning re≈øides by toleration;
No law forbids the youth to read;
For ≈øen≈øe, no tortures are decreed;
There ≈øtudy injures but the name,
And meets no puni≈øhment, but ≈øhame."
Thus reas'ning, Dick goes forth to find
A College ≈øuited to his mind;
But bred in di≈øtant woods, the Clown
Brings all his country-airs to town;
The odd addre≈øs with awkward grace,
That bows with all-averted face;
The half heard compliments, who≈øe note
Is ≈øwallow'd in the trembling throat;
The ≈øtiffen'd gait, the drawling tone,
By which his native place is known;
The blu≈øh, that looks, by va≈øt degrees,
Too much like mode≈øty to plea≈øe:
The proud di≈øplays of awkward dre≈øs,
That all the Country-fop expre≈øs,
The ≈øuit right gay, tho' much belated,
Who≈øe fa≈øhion's ≈øuperannuated;
The watch, depending far in ≈øtate,
Who≈øe iron chain might form a grate;
The ≈øilver buckle, dread to view,
O'er≈øhad'wing all the clum≈øy ≈øhoe;
The white-glov'd hand, that tries to peep
From ruffle, full five inches deep;
With fifty odd affairs be≈øide,
The foppi≈øhne≈øs of country-pride.
Poor Dick! tho' fir≈øt thy airs provoke
Th' ob≈øtrep'rous laugh and ≈øcornful joke,
Doom'd all the ridicule to ≈øtand,
While each gay dunce ≈øhall lend a hand;
Yet let not ≈øcorn di≈ømay thy hope
To ≈øhine a Witling and a Fop.
Ble≈øt impudence the prize ≈øhall gain,
And bid thee ≈øigh no more in vain.
Thy varied dre≈øs ≈øhall quickly ≈øhow
At once the ≈øpendthrift and the Beau.
With pert addre≈øs and noi≈øy tongue,
That ≈øcorns the fear of prating wrong,
'Mong≈øt li≈øtning coxcombs ≈øhalt thou ≈øhine,
And ev'ry voice ≈øhall echo thine.
As when, disjointed from the ≈øtock,
We view with ≈øcorn the ≈øhapele≈øs block,
The ≈økilful ≈øtatuary hews us
The wood in any form he chu≈øes;
So ≈øhall the arts of Fops in town
From thee ≈ømooth off the rugged clown,
The rubbi≈øh of thy mien ≈øhall clear,
Till all the Beau in pomp appear.
How ble≈øt the brainle≈øs Fop, who≈øe prai≈øe
Is doom'd to grace the≈øe happy days,
When wellbred Vice can genius teach,
And fame is placed in Folly's reach;
Impertinence all ta≈øtes can hit,
And ev'ry Ra≈øcal is a Wit.
The lowe≈øt dunce, without de≈øpairing,
May learn the true ≈øublime, of ≈øwearing,
Learn the nice art of je≈øts ob≈øcene,
(While Ladies wonder what they mean)
The heroi≈øm of brazen lungs,
The rhet'ric of eternal tongues;
While whim u≈øurps the name of ≈øpirit,
And impudence takes place of merit,
And ev'ry money'd Clown and Dunce
Commences Gentleman at once.
For now, by ea≈øy rules of trade,
Mechanic Gentlemen are made!
From handycrafts of fa≈øhion born;
Tho≈øe very arts ≈øo much their ≈øcorn.
To tailors half them≈øelves they owe,
Who make the clothes, that make the Beau.
Lo! from the ≈øeats, where (Fops to ble≈øs)
Learn'd Arti≈øts fix the forms of dre≈øs,
And ≈øit in con≈øultation grave,
On folded ≈økirt, or ≈øtraitned ≈øleeve,
The Coxcomb trips with ≈øprightly ha≈øte,
In all the flu≈øh of modern ta≈øte:
Oft turning, if the day be fair,
To view his ≈øhadow's graceful air;
Wellpleas'd with eager eye runs o'er
The laced ≈øuit glittring gay before;
The ruffle, where from open'd ve≈øt
The rubied brooch adorns the brea≈øt;
The coat with length'ning wai≈øt behind,
Who≈øe ≈øhort ≈økirts dangle in the wind;
The modi≈øh hat, who≈øe breadth contains
The mea≈øure of its owner's brains;
The ≈øtockings gay with ≈øilken hues;
The little toe-encircling ≈øhoes;
The cane, on who≈øe carv'd top is ≈øhown
And head ju≈øt emblem of his own;
While wrapt in ≈øelf, with lofty ≈øtride,
His little heart elate with pride,
He ≈øtruts in all the joys of ≈øhow,
That Tailors give, or Beaus can know.
And who for Beauty need repine,
That's ≈øold at ev'ry Barber's ≈øign;
Nor lies in features or complexion,
But curls di≈øpos'd in meet direction,
With ≈øtrong pomatum's grateful odour,
And quantum ≈øufficit of powder?
The≈øe charms can ≈øhed a ≈øprightly grace,
O'er the dull eye and clum≈øy face;
While the trim Dancing-ma≈øter's art
Shall ge≈øtures, trips and bows impart,
Give the gay piece its final touches,
And lend tho≈øe airs, would lure a Dutche≈øs.
Thus ≈øhines the form, nor aught behind,
The gifts that deck the Coxcomb's mind;
Then hear the daring mu≈øe di≈øclo≈øe
The ≈øen≈øe and Piety of Beaus.
To grace his ≈øpeech, let France be≈øtow
A ≈øet of compliments for ≈øhow;
Land of Politene≈øs! that affords
The trea≈øure of newfangled words,
And endle≈øs quantities di≈øbur≈øes
Of bows and compliments and cur≈øes:
The ≈øoft addre≈øs, with airs ≈øo ≈øweet,
That cringes at the Ladies feet;
The pert, vivacious, play-hou≈øe ≈øtyle,
That wakes the gay a≈ø≈øembly's ≈ømile;
Je≈øts that his brother-beaus may hit,
And pa≈øs with young Coquettes for wit,
And, priz'd by Fops of true di≈øcerning,
Outface the pedantry of learning.
Yet Learning too ≈øhall lend its aid,
To fill the Coxcomb's ≈øpongy head,
And ≈øtudious oft he ≈øhall peru≈øe
The labours of the Modern Mu≈øe.
From endle≈øs loads of Novels gain
Soft, ≈øimpring tales of am'rous pain,
With double meanings, neat and handy,
From Roche≈øter and Tri≈øtram Shandy.
The blundring aid of weak Reviews,
That forge the fetters of the mu≈øe,
Shall give him airs of criticizing
On faults of books, he ne'er ≈øet eyes on.
The Magazines ≈øhall teach the fa≈øhion,
And common-place of conver≈øation,
And where his knowledge fails, afford
The aid of many a ≈øounding word.
Then lea≈øt Religion he ≈øhould need,

Of pious Hume, Voltaire & Bolingbroke are three of the mo≈øt noted Dei≈øtical Writers, who≈øe admirers are more numerous, even in America, than perhaps many of our hone≈øt Country-readers may imagine. It will be ea≈øily di≈øcerned, that my de≈øign was to draw a compleat character of a fir≈øt-rate Coxcomb, and not to confine my≈øelf merely to the inferior, ≈øecond-handed, imitative Beaus of this country, among whom, though we can boa≈øt of ≈øome promi≈øing Geniu≈øes, yet Foppery ≈øeems to be but ju≈øt cleverly dawning. Hume he'll learn his creed,
By ≈øtronge≈øt demon≈øtration ≈øhown,
Evince that nothing can be known;
Take arguments, unvex'd by doubt,
On Voltaire's tru≈øt, or go without;
'Gain≈øt Scripture rail in modern lore,
As thou≈øand fools have rail'd before:
Or pleas'd, a nicer art di≈øplay
T' expound its doctrines all away,
Suit it to modern ta≈øte and fa≈øhions
By various notes and emendations;
The rules the ten commands contain,
With new provi≈øos well explain;
Prove all Religion was but fa≈øhion,
Beneath the Jewi≈øh di≈øpen≈øation,
A ceremonious law, deep-hooded
In types and figures long exploded;
Its ≈øtubborn fetters all unfit
For the≈øe free times of Go≈øpel-light,
This Rake's Millennium, ≈øince the day
When Sabbaths fir≈øt were done away;
Since Shame, the wor≈øt of deadly fiends,
On Virtue, as its 'Squire, attends;
Since Pandar-con≈øcience holds the door,
And lewdne≈øs is a vice no more;
And fools may, ≈øwift as crimes convey 'em,
Flee to their place, and no man ≈øtay 'em.
Alike his poignant with di≈øplays
The darkne≈øs of the former days,
When men the paths of duty ≈øought,
And own'd what revelation taught;
E'er human rea≈øon grew ≈øo bright,
Men could ≈øee all things by its light,
And ≈øummon'd Scripture to appear,
And ≈øtand before its bar ≈øevere,
To clear its page from charge of fiction,
And an≈øwer pleas of contradiction;
E'er my≈øt'ries fir≈øt were held in ≈øcorn,
Or Bolingbroke, or Hume were born.
And now the Fop, with great energy,
Levels at Prie≈øtcraft and the Clergy,
At holy cant and godly pray'rs,
And bigot's hypocritic airs;
Mu≈øters each vet'ran je≈øt to aid,
Calls Piety the Par≈øon's trade;
Cries out 'tis ≈øhame, pa≈øt all abiding,
The world ≈øhould ≈øtill be ≈øo Prie≈øt-ridden;
Applauds free thought, that ≈øcorns controul,
And gen'rous noblene≈øs of ≈øoul,
That acts its plea≈øure, good or evil,
And fears nor Deity, nor Devil.
The≈øe ≈øtanding topics never fail
To prompt our little Wits to rail,
With mimic droll'ry of grimace,
And pleas'd impertinence of face,
'Gain≈øt Virtue arm their feeble forces,
And ≈øound the charge in peals of cur≈øes.
Ble≈øt be his a≈øhes! (under ground
If any particles be found)
Who, friendly to the Coxcomb-race,
Fir≈øt taught the≈øe arts of common-place,
The≈øe topics fine, on which the Beau
May all his little wits be≈øtow,
Secure the ≈øimple laugh to rai≈øe,
And gain the Dunce's palm of prai≈øe.
For where's the theme that Beaus could hit
With lea≈øt ≈øimilitude of wit,
Did not Religion and the Prie≈øt
Supply materials for the je≈øt?
The poor in pur≈øe, with metals vile
For current coins, the world beguile;
The poor in brain, for genuine wit
Pa≈øs off a viler counterfeit;
(While various thus their doom appears,
The≈øe lo≈øe their ≈øouls, and tho≈øe their ears)
The want of fancy, whim ≈øupplies,
And native humour, mad caprice;
Loud noi≈øe for argument goes off,
For mirth polite, the ribald's ≈øcoff;
For ≈øen≈øe, lewd droll'ries entertain us,
And wit is mimick'd by prophanene≈øs.
Thus 'twixt the Tailor and the Player,
And Hume, and Tri≈øtram and Voltaire,
Complete in modern trim array'd.
The Clock work-Gentleman is made;
As thou≈øand Fops e'er Dick have ≈øhone,
In airs, which Dick e'er long ≈øhall own.
But not immediate from the Clown,
He gains this zenith of renown;
Slow dawns the Coxcomb's op'ning ray:
Rome was not fini≈øh'd in a day.
Perfection is the work of time;
Gradual he mounts the height ≈øublime;
Fir≈øt ≈øhines abroad with bolder grace,
In ≈øuits of ≈øecond-handed lace,
And learns by rote, like ≈øtudious play'rs,
The fop's infinity of airs;
Till merit, to full ripene≈øs grown,
By con≈øtancy attains the crown.
Now ≈øhould our tale at large proceed
Here I might tell, and you might read
At college next how Dick went on,
And prated much and ≈øtudied none;
Yet ≈øhone with fair, unborrow'd ray,
And ≈øteer'd where nature led the way.
What tho' each academic Science
Bade all his efforts bold defiance!
What tho' in Algebra his ≈øtation
Was negative in each equation;
Tho' in A≈øtronomy ≈øurvey'd,
His con≈øtant cour≈øe was retrograde;
O'er Newton's ≈øy≈øtem tho' he ≈øleeps,
And finds his wits in dark eclip≈øe!
His talents prov'd of highe≈øt price
At all the arts of Cards and Dice;
His genius turn'd, with greate≈øt ≈økill,
To whi≈øt, loo, cribbage and quadrille,
And taught, to ev'ry rival's ≈øhame,
Each nice di≈øtinction of the game.
As noonday ≈øun, the ca≈øe is plain,
Nature has nothing made in vain.
The blind mole cannot fly; 'tis found
His genius leads him under ground;
The man, that was not made to think,
Was born to game, and ≈øwear, and drink:
Let Fops defiance bid to ≈øatire,
Mind Tully's rule, and follow nature.
Yet here the Mu≈øe, of Dick, mu≈øt tell
He ≈øhone in active ≈øeenes as well;
The foremo≈øt place in riots held;
In all the gifts of noi≈øe excell'd;
His tongue, the bell, who≈øe rattling din wou'd
Summon the Rake's nocturnal ≈øynod;
Swore with a grace, that ≈øeem'd de≈øign'd
To emulate th' infernal kind,
Nor only make their realms his due,
But learn, betimes, their language too;
And well expert in arts polite,
Drank wine by quarts to mend his ≈øight,
(For he that drinks, till all things reel,
Sees double, and that's twice as well)
And e'er its force confin'd his feet,
Led out his mob to ≈øcour the ≈øtreet;
Made all authority his may game,
And ≈øtrain'd his little wits to plague 'em.
Then, ev'ry crime aton'd with ea≈øe,
Pro meritis receiv'd degrees;
And ≈øoon, as fortune chanc'd to fall,
His Father died and left him all:
Then, bent to gain all modern fa≈øhions,
He ≈øail'd to vi≈øit foreign nations,
Re≈øolv'd, by toil unaw'd t' import,
The follies of the Briti≈øh Court;
But in his cour≈øe o'erlook'd whate'er
Was learn'd or valu'd, rich or rare.
As fire electric draws together
Each hair and ≈øtraw and du≈øt and feather,
The travell'd Dunce collects betimes
The levities of other climes;
And when long toil has giv'n ≈øucce≈øs,
Returns his native land to ble≈øs,
A Patriot-fop, that ≈øtruts by rules,
And Knight of all the ≈øhire of fools.
The prai≈øe of other learning lo≈øt,
To know the world is all his boa≈øt,
By conduct teach our Country-wigeons,
How Coxcombs ≈øhine in other regions,
Di≈øplay his travell'd airs and fa≈øhions,
And ≈øcoff at College-educations.
Whoe'er at College points his ≈øneer,
Proves that him≈øelf learn'd nothing there,
And wi≈øely makes his hone≈øt aim
To pay the mutual debt of ≈øhame.
Mean while our Hero's anxious care
Was all employ'd to plea≈øe the Fair;
With vows of love and airs polite,
Oft ≈øighing at ≈øome Lady's feet;
Pleas'd, while he thus in form addre≈øt her,
With his own gracefulne≈øs of ge≈øture,
And gaudy flatt'ry, that di≈øplays
A ≈øtudied elegance of phra≈øe.
So gay at balls the Coxcomb ≈øhone,
He thought the Female world his own.
By beauty's charms he ne'er was fir'd;
He flatter'd where the world admir'd.
Him≈øelf (≈øo well he priz'd de≈øert)
Po≈ø≈øe≈øt his own unrivall'd heart;
Nor charms, nor chance, nor change could move
The firm foundations of his love:
His heart, ≈øo con≈øtant and ≈øo wi≈øe,
Pur≈øued what Sages old advi≈øe,
Bade others ≈øeek for fame or pelf;
His only ≈øtudy was Him≈øelf.
Yet Dick allow'd the Fair, de≈øert,
Nor wholly ≈øcorn'd them in his heart;
There was an end (as oft he ≈øaid)
For which alone the Sex were made,
Whereto, of nature's rules ob≈øervant,
He ≈øtrove to render them ≈øub≈øervient;
And held the Fair by inclination,
Were form'd exactly for their ≈øtation,
That real virtue ne'er could find
Her lodging in a female mind;
Quoted from Pope, in phra≈øe ≈øo ≈ømart,
That all the Sex are "rakes at heart,"
And prais'd Mahomet's ≈øen≈øe, who holds
That Women ne'er were born with ≈øouls.
Thus ble≈øt, our Hero ≈øaw his name
Rank'd in the foremot li≈øts of fame.
What tho' the learn'd, the good, the wi≈øe,
His light, affected airs de≈øpi≈øe!
What tho' the Fair, of higher mind,
With brighter thought and ≈øen≈øe refin'd,
Who≈øe fancy ro≈øe on nobler wing,
Scorn'd the vain, gilt, gay, noi≈øy thing!
Each light Coquette ≈øpread forth her charms,
And lur'd the Hero to her arms.
For Beaus and light Coquettes, by fate
Were each de≈øign'd the other's mate,
By in≈øtinct love, for each may find
It's likene≈øs in the other's mind;
Then let the wi≈øer ≈øort de≈øert 'em,
For 'twere a ≈øin to try to part 'em.
Nor did the coxcomb-loving climate
To the≈øe alone his prai≈øes limit.
Each gayer Fop of modern days
Allow'd to Dick the foremo≈øt prai≈øe,
Borrow'd his ≈øtyle, his airs, grimace,
And aped his modi≈øh form of dre≈øs.
Ev'n Some, with ≈øen≈øe endued, felt hopes
And rais'd ambition to be fops:
But Men of ≈øen≈øe, 'tis fix'd by fate,
Are Coxcombs but of ≈øecond rate.
The pert and lively Dunce alone
Can ≈øteer the cour≈øe that Dick has ≈øhown;
The lively Dunce alone can climb
The ≈øummit, where he ≈øhines ≈øublime.
But ah! how ≈øhort the faire≈øt name
Stands on the ≈ølipp'ry ≈øteep of fame!
The noble≈øt heights we're ≈øoone≈øt giddy on:
The ≈øun ne'er ≈øtays in his meridian;
The brighte≈øt ≈øtars mu≈øt quickly ≈øet;
And Dick has deeply run in debt.
Now what avails his ≈øplendid ≈øhow,
With all the arts, that grace the Beau!
Not all his oaths can Duns di≈ømay,
Or deadly Bailiffs fright away;
Not all his compliments can bail,
Or minuets dance him from the jail.
Law not the lea≈øt re≈øpect can give
To the laced coat, or ruffled ≈øleeve.
Off fly at once, in ≈øadde≈øt woe,
The dre≈øs and trappings of the Beau;
His ≈øplendid ornaments mu≈øt fall,
And all is lo≈øt; for the≈øe were all.
What then remains? in health's decline,
By lewdne≈øs, luxury and wine,
Worn by di≈øea≈øe, with pur≈øe too ≈øhallow,
To lead in fa≈øhions, or to follow,
The meteor's gaudy light is gone;
Lone Age with ha≈øty ≈øtep comes on;
The charms he once with pride di≈øplay'd,
All vani≈øh'd into empty ≈øhade;
And only left, in tawdry ≈øhow,
The ≈øuperannuated Beau.
How pale the pal≈øied Fop appears,
Low-≈øhivring in the vale of years;
The gho≈øt of all his former days,
When folly lent the ear of prai≈øe.
And Beaus with pleas'd attention hung
On accents of his chatt'ring tongue.
Now all tho≈øe days of plea≈øure o'er,
That chatt'ring tongue mu≈øt prate no more.
From ev'ry place, that ble≈øs'd his hopes,
He's elbow'd out by younger Fops.
Each plea≈øing thought unknown, that chears
The ≈øadne≈øs of declining years,
In lonely age he ≈øinks forlorn,
Of all, and ev'n him≈øelf, the ≈øcorn.
The Coxcomb's cour≈øe were wondrous clever,
Would health and money la≈øt forever,
Did Con≈øcience never break the charm,
Nor fears of future worlds alarm.
But oh, ≈øince youth and years decay,
And life's vain follies fleet away,
Since Age has no re≈øpect for Beaus,
And Death the gaudy ≈øcene mu≈øt clo≈øe,
Happy the Man, who≈øe early bloom
Provides for endle≈øs years to come;
That learning ≈øeeks, who≈øe u≈øeful gain
Repays the cour≈øe of ≈øtudious pain,
Who≈øe fame the thankful age ≈øhall rai≈øe,
And future times repeat its prai≈øe;
Attains that heart-felt peace of mind,
To all the will of heav'n re≈øign'd,
Which calms in youth, the bla≈øt of rage,
Adds ≈øweete≈øt hope to ≈øinking age,
With valued u≈øe prolongs the breath,
And gives a placid ≈ømile to death.
Then let us ≈øcorn the prai≈øe that ≈øprings
From gaudy, ≈øublunary things.
Hate the vain joys, that vice can claim,
To nobler thoughts exalt our aim,
With ardour ≈øeek th' immortal prize,
And ≈øeize our portion in the ≈økies.

div.p: To be publi≈øhed by the next Commencement at farthe≈øt, The Progre≈øs of DULNESS, PART THIRD and LAST: Otherwi≈øe called, The Progre≈øs of COQUETRY, OR An E≈ø≈øay on Female EDUCATION; For the u≈øe of the Ladies and their Parents.
